content.rendered:
Celebrate 4/20 in style with an evening dedicated to the day in the Laser Dome. Hear your favorite weed-related songs, including songs by Wu-Tang Clan, Childish Gambino, Luniz, and more.

  • 7:30 p.m.: Laser 4/20
  • 9 p.m.: Laser Mac Miller

content.rendered:
Join the region’s business, philanthropic, and civic leaders at the PacSci Ignite Luncheon—an unforgettable event that celebrates the power of curiosity and the innovators shaping our future. This is not just any event. It’s the gathering where the region’s community members and leaders come together to ensure every child has the opportunity to thrive through STEM education.

We’re excited to announce that Seattle Mayor Bruce Harrell will be this year’s keynote speaker. His leadership and passion for innovation and community development will set the tone for an inspiring afternoon.

Our goal for this luncheon fundraiser is to raise $600,000 to sustain and expand PacSci’s vital educational programs. Your support will help us deliver inspiring experiences that spark curiosity, ignite a passion for discovery, and make science education accessible to all in our community. Together, we can nurture the next generation of thinkers, innovators, and explorers!

The Ignite Luncheon is free to attend, but registration is required. Guests will be encouraged to make a donation of $500 or more during the program. Donors contributing $500 or more will be recognized as members of PacSci’s Igniter Donor Society and receive a complimentary membership.

Details

Day & Time

Tuesday, May 13

  • 11 a.m.: Coffee reception with table hosts and PacSci educators
  • 11:45 a.m.–1 p.m.: Lunch and Program

Location

Fisher Pavilion, located within the Seattle Center

Parking

Available at Climate Pledge Arena – 1st Ave Parking Lot, entering at 225 Warren Ave N, Seattle, 98109. This parking offer is available from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. A validation sticker will be provided at the Luncheon to ensure your parking is covered.

Can’t Make it to the luncheon?

Please consider making a donation in lieu of attendance. Your gift will be counted in our Challenge Pool of matching gifts and help inspire others to extend their support. Gifts of $500 or more qualify for PacSci’s Igniter Donors Society.

give a gift

Contact

About Ignite Luncheon

The Ignite Luncheon is PacSci’s largest fundraising event of the year, generating funds for sustained and expanded STEM education for children and families. These funds fuel scholarships for summer camp students, supplemental funding for Science on Wheels outreach programs, development of groundbreaking exhibitions, and more!

As access to STEM education becomes more critical, PacSci will expand its outreach to meet the needs of educators and students statewide, beginning right here in Seattle. Last year, 350 registered guests generated more than $500,000 in charitable support for PacSci. With your help, this year’s luncheon will have an even greater impact on the community. Featuring special speakers and live science demonstrations, this event is a fun and engaging opportunity to connect with your fellow science-lovers, learn about the future of Pacific Science Center, and to join us in advancing science education for all.

Thank you to our Generous Sponsors:

Additional support provided by The Baldwin Group, Battelle – Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Charlie’s Produce, NWPS, Puget Sound Energy, Sellen Construction, Umpqua Bank, Climate Pledge Arena and Kaspars Catering & Events.

excerpt.rendered: Join us to raise funds that will provide our critical thinkers of tomorrow with hands-on science experiences today.

title.rendered: Live at the Laser Dome: KEXP DJ in Residence

content.rendered:
PacSci and KEXP’s Live at the Laser Dome: KEXP DJ in Residence is excited to welcome Audioasis’ Kennady Quille for March, April, and May.

Every three months on the first Wednesday of the month, a different KEXP DJ will curate a series of monthly playlists for the Laser Dome. The select DJ will then perform a live set accompanying the laser performance once a month at the Laser Dome.

Meet the dj

Our spring residency is with DJ Kennady from KEXP’s Audioasis.

She takes a ton of pride in spotlighting the amazing artists in the beautiful PNW on Audioasis. Kennady was born and raised in the Seattle area and has been involved with local nonprofits since they were in high school. She got her start at KEXP through the youth DJ program 90.TEEN at 17 and has been on air ever since!

Audioasis is KEXP’s long-running Northwest music show with local music from all pockets and genres of the Pacific Northwest, including artists based in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Alaska, or British Columbia.

content.rendered:
Who says Pacific Science Center is just for kids? We’re thrilled to introduce Sound Lab, our newest 21+ after-hours event where science meets the underground music scene!

Get ready to dance the night away as we transform the lower levels of our Tinker Tank lab into an electrifying dance floor. Lights off, music on—this is your night to unwind and connect!

We’ve partnered with Restless Planet known for quality dance music, fostering creativity & community in the Pacific NW.

Patchwerks for a Pop Up Synth Petting Zoo

Explore a variety of electronic music making equipment, play with sounds, make a song, and get tips from sound design professionals.

Top-tier DJs, Music Creation Stations, and a chance to dance in the iconic Pacific Science Center.

Grab your crew, and join us for a night of music, community, and discovery at Pacific Science Center’s Sound Lab.

Come for the science. Stay for the beats.

tickets

Early Bird

  • Members: $17
  • Igniters: Free
  • General: $22

General

  • Members: $22
  • Igniters: Free
  • General: $27

Plus, special offer – buy two get the third 50% off!

title.rendered: Science & a Movie: The Trouble with Wolves

content.rendered:
Join PacSci for a special free screening of the documentary, The Trouble with Wolves, an exploration of the complex and often controversial relationship between wolves and humans in the American West. The documentary delves into the challenges and rewards surrounding wolf reintroduction and conservation efforts, highlighting differing viewpoints from livestock producers, conservationists, and wildlife managers. This screening is the 2023 edition, featuring updates from the initial film release in 2018.

Wolf Haven International is an internationally recognized wolf sanctuary that has rescued and provided a lifetime home for over 300 displaced, captive-born animals since 1982 under the mission “to conserve and protect wolves and their habitat.” Wolf Haven is accredited by both the Global Federation of Animal Sanctuaries and the American Sanctuary Association. Wolf Haven is located in Tenino, Washington – approximately 12 miles south of the Washington State Capital in Olympia.

Tickets

All tickets are free.

schedule

  • Doors: 6 p.m.
  • Movie: 6:15 p.m.
  • Q&A: 7:30 p.m.

About the speaker

Amy Porter

Amy Porter is a wildlife conservation biologist with 25 years of experience working on scientific research, nature-based education, and community engagement projects in the United States, Caribbean, Latin America, and Africa.

She grew up in Washington and has been a passionate naturalist in the area since she was young. Amy has worked extensively with birds, otters, primates, and now wolves. Currently, she is the Director of Conservation at Wolf Haven International where she is involved with both wolf and prairie conservation.

content.rendered:
Sensory-Friendly Hours at Pacific Science Center are designed for learners of all ages with sensory sensitivities who benefit from a calmer and more accessible environment.

Formerly known as Exploration for All, these special events feature adjusted lighting and sound to ensure a welcoming and engaging experience for all attendees.

What to Expect

  • Softened lighting and reduced noise levels throughout the space.
  • Adjusted hands-on activities and exhibits tailored for a sensory-friendly experience.
  • Access to the Sensory Lounge, a quiet retreat available during all visits to PacSci.
  • A free social narrative is available online year-round to help guests plan their visit.

Reserve your tickets online. Walk-up tickets are also available at the North Entrance.

Contact us with any question or need more information. Learn more about Accessibility at PacSci.

Upcoming dates

Generous Support Provided By:

Additional support comes from more than 2,500 individuals, companies, and foundations that donate to the Science Center each year. Learn more about ways you can support the Access to Science Pipeline and Pacific Science Center.

content.rendered:
Join PacSci on Saturday, April 12, for a day dedicated to exploring the exciting world of polar science. In partnership with the University of Washington’s Polar Science Center and Applied Physics Laboratory, Polar Science Day features hands-on activities and interactive demonstrations that highlight the work of scientists investigating some of the most remote environments on Earth. You’ll have the opportunity to engage with community scientists and learn how they gather information to answer questions about the Arctic and Antarctic regions.

Whether you’re interested in ice sheets, scientific instruments, or polar wildlife, there’s something for everyone. Don’t miss this unique chance to experience polar science firsthand and discover the research helping us better understand the farthest corners of our planet.

Special Events

Science & a Movie: Arctic: Our Frozen Planet

Doors: 10:45 a.m.
Starts: 11 a.m.

Celebrate Polar Science Day at PacSci with a special Science and a Movie. This event starts with a presentation from local polar bear expert, Dr. Eric Regehr, who will share his experience working with polar bears and studying the challenges they face in our rapidly changing climate.

Following the presentation, enjoy a screening of Arctic: Our Frozen Planet, an IMAX documentary by the BBC, featuring Eric and his team in the field. This stunning film offers a rare look into the lives of iconic Arctic wildlife, from polar bears navigating ice floes to belugas, narwhals, and muskox fighting for survival in the harshest of environments. Immerse yourself in the breathtaking beauty of the Arctic’s frozen landscapes!

This film is rated G for General Audiences. Due to the nature of the presentation, this event is recommended for guests ages 5 and up.

About the Speaker

Dr. Eric Regehr is a Principal Quantitative Ecologist at the University of Washington’s Polar Science Center.

He has spent 25 years studying the population dynamics of terrestrial and marine wildlife in relation to climate warming and harvest. Eric’s work is focused on polar bears, and he has been involved in studies on 13 of the world’s 19 polar bear subpopulations. Recognizing humans as a key part of many ecosystems, Eric is most interested in applied research that is relevant to both animals and people.

Planetarium shows

Earth: Pole to Pole

Times: 12:15 p.m. and 2:15 p.m.

Explore the important role that the polar regions play in shaping our planet into the world we call home. With a view from space, we’ll uncover the distinct features of the polar regions and learn how scientists use this unique perspective to address some of Earth’s biggest questions. Joining us for this program is Katie Braun, a graduate student from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, who specializes in studying permafrost landscapes using cutting-edge remote sensing tools like drones and satellites. Katie will share her firsthand experiences working in the Arctic and will be available to answer questions from guests.

Special Thanks to:

This event is a partnership between PacSci and the University of Washington’s Polar Science Center and Applied Physics Laboratory.

excerpt.rendered: Polar Science Day features hands-on activities and interactive demonstrations that highlight the work of scientists investigating some of the most remote environments on Earth.

title.rendered: To Live Is To Dream: A Northwest Tribute To David Lynch

content.rendered:
The independent cinemas of the greater Seattle area unite to celebrate the late, great David Lynch, one of our region’s greatest artists. SIFF, Northwest Film Forum, The Beacon, The Grand Illusion, and North Bend Theatre – joined by Pacific Science Center’s IMAX theater – present a year-long, region-wide retrospective of Lynch’s towering body of work. Join us to celebrate the legacy of this legendary artist with To Live Is To Dream: A Northwest Tribute To David Lynch.

schedule

tickets

All tickets for David Lynch films at Pacific Science Center will be $7.77 to honor Lynch’s favorite number.

excerpt.rendered: Seattle’s independent cinemas, including PacSci IMAX theaters, present a yearlong, region-wide retrospective of David Lynch’s filmography.

content.rendered:
Once a month, homeschool families are invited to enjoy a day of discovery at Pacific Science Center with special discounted pricing. Experience hands-on learning, explore fascinating exhibits, and enjoy laser and planetarium shows*—all included with general admission.

Pricing

  • General Admission: $15 per person
  • IMAX® Add-On: +$5 per person

No reservations are needed—just let us know you’re a homeschool group when you arrive at the North Gate entrance to purchase your tickets!

*Daytime laser and planetarium shows require a free timed-entry ticket on a first-come basis at the admissions gate.

IMAX® is a registered trademark of IMAX Corporation.

excerpt.rendered: Once a month, homeschool families are invited to enjoy a day of discovery at Pacific Science Center with special discounted pricing.
